TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit UINavigationController extends MonoTouch.UIKit.UIViewController

Docs.summary: A UIViewController for managing hierarchical navigation.

remarks.para: The MonoTouch API supports two styles of event notification: the Objective-C style that uses a delegate class or the C# style using event notifications.

The C# style allows the user to add or remove event handlers at runtime by assigning to the events of properties of this class. Event handlers can be anyone of a method, an anonymous methods or a lambda expression. Using the C# style events or properties will override any manual settings to the Objective-C Delegate or WeakDelegate settings.

The Objective-C style requires the user to create a new class derived from class and assign it to the property. Alternatively, for low-level control, by creating a class derived from which has every entry point properly decorated with an [Export] attribute. The instance of this object can then be assigned to the property.

Prior to iOS 7, the screen area covered by the and was excluded from the area of the . In iOS 7, the and float over the child controllers' . Application developers who wish to modify this behavior should manipulate the property.

Docs.remarks: This constructor is provided to allow the class to be initialized from an unarchiver (for example, during NIB deserialization).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t) cil managed

Docs.summary: Constructor to call on derived classes to skip initialization and merely allocate the object.

remarks.para: This constructor should be called by derived classes when they completely construct the object in managed code and merely want the runtime to allocate and initialize the NSObject. This is required to implement the two-step initialization process that Objective-C uses, the first step is to perform the object allocation, the second step is to initialize the object. When you invoke the constructor that takes the NSObjectFlag.Empty you taking advantage of a direct path that goes all the way up to NSObject to merely allocate the object's memory and bind the Objective-C and C# objects together. The actual initialization of the object is up to you.

This constructor is typically used by the binding generator to allocate the object, but prevent the actual initialization to take place. Once the allocation has taken place, the constructor has to initialize the object. With constructors generated by the binding generator this means that it manually invokes one of the "init" methods to initialize the object.
It is your responsibility to completely initialize the object if you chain up using the NSObjectFlag.Empty path.

In general, if your constructors invokes the NSObjectFlag.Empty base implementation, then it should be calling an Objective-C init method. If this is not the case, you should instead chain to the proper constructor in your class.

The argument value is ignored and merely ensures that the only code that is executed is the construction phase is the basic NSObject allocation and runtime type registration. Typically the chaining would look like this:

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.UIKit.UIViewController rootViewController) cil managed

Docs.param: The root controller to add to the top of the UINavigationController's controller stack.
Docs.summary: Constructor that takes a to use as the topmost controller in the UINavigationController's controller stack.
Docs.remarks: The UINavigationController class manages a stack of view controllers. The view for the controller passed into this constructor, in the rootViewController parameter, will be presented initially when the UINavigationController is loaded.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(native int handle) cil managed

Docs.summary: A constructor used when creating managed representations of unmanaged objects; Called by the runtime.

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a pointer to an unmanaged Objective-C object. You should not invoke this method directly, instead you should call the GetNSObject method as it will prevent two instances of a managed object to point to the same native object.

The handle for this class.
Docs.value: The pointer to the Objective-C class.
Docs.remarks: Each MonoTouch class mirrors an unmanaged Objective-C class. This value contains the pointer to the Objective-C class, it is similar to calling objc_getClass with the object name.

Docs.summary: An instance of the MonoTouch.UIKit.UINavigationControllerDelegate model class which acts as the class delegate.

value.para: The instance of the MonoTouch.UIKit.UINavigationControllerDelegate model class

remarks.para: The delegate instance assigned to this object will be used to handle events or provide data on demand to this class.
When setting the Delegate or WeakDelegate values events will be delivered to the specified instance instead of being delivered to the C#-style events
This is the strongly typed version of the object, use the WeakDelegate property instead if you want to merely assign a class derived from NSObject that has been decorated with [Export] attributes.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void Dispose(bool disposing) cil managed

param.name: disposing
param.para: If set to , the method is invoked directly and will dispose manage and unmanaged resources; If set to the method is being called by the garbage collector finalizer and should only release unmanaged resources.

Docs.summary: Releases the resources used by the UINavigationController object.

remarks.para: This Dispose method releases the resources used by the UINavigationController class.

This method is called by both the Dispose() method and the object finalizer (Finalize). When invoked by the Dispose method, the parameter disposing is set to and any managed object references that this object holds are also disposed or released; when invoked by the object finalizer, on the finalizer thread the value is set to .

Calling the Dispose method when you are finished using the UINavigationController ensures that all external resources used by this managed object are released as soon as possible. Once you have invoked the Dispose method, the object is no longer useful and you should no longer make any calls to it.

For more information on how to override this method and on the Dispose/IDisposable pattern, read the ``Implementing a Dispose Method'' document at http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/fs2xkftw.aspx

Docs.summary: Represents the value associated with the constant UINavigationControllerHideShowBarDuration
A gesture recognizer for the left-edge-to-interior "back" gesture.

remarks.para: iOS 7 added a new standard gesture, in which the application user drags from the left side of the screen towards the interior. This gesture is intended to be used for backwards navigation; in the case of a , it should normally be associated with an "interactive pop" of the current .

Docs.summary: The for the UINavigationController.
Docs.remarks: The UINavigation controller manages the navigation bar, adding items to it, such as the title, based upon the of the controller currently on the screen, which will be the controller at the top of the UINavigationController's stack. The back button of the navigation bar will automatically pop the controller, causing the previously displayed controller to move to the top of the stack and its view to appear. The UINavigationBar can also have other instances added to it.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool NavigationBarHidden { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Allows the navigation bar to be hidden.
Docs.remarks: Hides or shows the navigationBar without using animation.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class MonoTouch.UIKit.UIViewController[] PopToRootViewController(bool animated) cil managed

Docs.param: A boolean indicating if the transition back to the root controller should be animated.
Docs.returns: An array of view controller that were popped from the stack in the process of returning to the root controller.
Docs.remarks: After this call, the root controller will be at the top of the UINavigationController's stack, and the root controller's view will be displayed by the navigation controller.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UIViewController[] PopToViewController (MonoTouch.UIKit.UIViewController viewController, bool animated);

A boolean indicating if the transition back to the root controller should be animated.
Docs.returns: An array of view controller that were popped from the stack in the process of returning to the root controller.
Docs.remarks: The UINavigationController will pop view controllers until the specified controller is at the top of the stack, after which it's view will be displayed.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class MonoTouch.UIKit.UIViewController PopViewControllerAnimated(bool animated) cil managed

Docs.param: A boolean indicating if the transition back to the root controller should be animated.
Docs.summary: Pops the controller currrently at the top of the stack
Docs.returns: The view controller popped from the stack
Docs.remarks: When the controller is popped from the stack, the UINavigationController will display the view of the controller that moves to the top of the navigation stack.

Docs.summary: Pushes a view controller onto the UINavigationController's navigation stack.
Docs.remarks: The specified controller is pushed onto the stack and the navigation controller will update its display to show this controller's view. There are a couple limitations. First, the controller must not already be part of the navigation controller's stack. Second, The controller cannot be a

Docs.param: The array of controllers to put into the navigation stack
A boolean to control if the topmost controller's transition should be animated.
Docs.summary: Replaces the controllers in the navigation controller's navigation stack.
Docs.remarks: The last controller in the array will be placed at the top of the navigation stack.

Docs.summary: Retruns the toolbar for the navigation controller.
Docs.remarks: Do not modify this toolbar directly. It should be modified only by the controller in the navigation controller's stack that contains it. The reason for having this property is so an action sheet can be presented from the toolbar.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool ToolbarHidden { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Controls visibility of the toolbar
Docs.remarks: Allows the toolbar to shown or hidden without using animation.

Docs.summary: The view controller currently at the top of the navigation controller's stack.
Docs.remarks: Returns the view controller currently at the top of the navigation controller's stack, whihc will change as the user navigates through the application.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UIViewController[] ViewControllers { get; set; }

Docs.summary: The view controllers currently on the navigation controller's stack.
Docs.remarks: Returns an array of controllers currently on the navigation controller's navigation stack, with the root controller being at the 0 index in the array.

Docs.summary: The view controller whose view is currently on the screen.
Docs.remarks: This will be either the view controller at the top of the stack, or one that was presented modally.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObject WeakDelegate { get; set; }

Docs.summary: An object that can respond to the delegate protocol for this type

value.para: The instance that will respond to events and data requests.

remarks.para: The delegate instance assigned to this object will be used to handle events or provide data on demand to this class.
When setting the Delegate or WeakDelegate values events will be delivered to the specified instance instead of being delivered to the C#-style events

Methods must be decorated with the [Export ("selectorName")] attribute to respond to each method from the protocol. Alternatively use the Delegate method which is strongly typed and does not require the [Export] attributes on methods.
